title: PCT 35: A woman kills a great serpent
author: Coming-Day

sentences.original: kîtahtawê iskwêw otawâsimisah wîcêwêw, êh-nâtahkik mînisah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê iskwêw otawâsimisa wîcêwêw ê-nâtahkik mînisa
sentences.english: Once a woman went with her children to get berries.

sentences.original: sîpîhk êkotah êh-âpahwâcik misatimwah; êkotah ê-wîh-kapêsicik.
sentences.text: sîpîhk êkota ê-âpahwâcik misatimwa êkota ê-wî-kapêsicik
sentences.english: At the river they unharnessed their horses, planning to camp there.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah sipwêhtêwak, êh-pimohtêcik, mînisah ê-wîh-otinahkik.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa sipwêhtêwak ê-pimohtêcik mînisa ê-wî-otinahkik
sentences.english: Then they went from there, on foot, to take berries.

sentences.original: pinasiwêwak sîpîhk.
sentences.english: They went down  to the river.

sentences.original: êh-wâpahtahk awa iskwêw mînisah, êkotah otinam.
sentences.text: ê-wâpahtahk awa iskwêw mînisa êkota otinam
sentences.english: Where the woman saw berries, she took them.

sentences.original: kotakah wâpahtam; êkotê itohtêw.
sentences.english: She saw some more; she went there.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kêkway kâ-wâpahtahk, ostikwâniyiw êh-wâpahtamowât.
sentences.english: Suddenly she saw something;  she saw some creature's head.

sentences.original: misi-kinêpik! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “A great serpent!” she thought.

sentences.original: otinêw asiniyah êh-pakamahwât, êh-nipahât.
sentences.english: She took a stone and struck it so as to kill it.

sentences.original: êkosi mistik otinam, êh-itohtêt êh-pakamahwât;
sentences.english: Then she took a stick and went up to it and beat it;

sentences.original: nipahêw,
sentences.english: she killed it;

sentences.original: kâ-wâpamât tâwayihk oskahtikoyihk otêskanah êh-kikamoyit, êh-pêyakoyit.
sentences.text: kâ-wâpamât tâwayihk oskahtikoyihk otêskana ê-kikamoyit ê-pêyakoyit
sentences.english: and then she saw that in the middle of its forehead it had a single horn.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-otihciyit kinêpikwah, tâpiskôc sôniyâw ostikwân êsinâkwaniyik.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-otihciyit kinêpikwa tâpiskôc sôniyâw ostikwân êsinâkwaniyik
sentences.english: And the serpent's head looked like bright metal.
sentences.footnote: LB on {êh-otihciyit}:  Meaning unknown; probably error.

sentences.original: namoya wâpamêw tân êyikohk êy-iskosiyit ôhi kinêpikwah kâh-nîpahât.
sentences.text: namôya wâpamêw tâni iyikohk ê-iskosiyit ôhi kinêpikwa kâ-nipahât
sentences.english: She could not see how long this serpent was which she had killed.

sentences.original: mitoni ê-sôhkêyimot aw iskwêw, kâh-nipahât ôhi kinêpikwah.
sentences.text: mitoni ê-sôhkêyimot awa iskwêw kâ-nipahât ôhi kinêpikwa
sentences.english: Very brave was this  woman, to have slain that serpent.

sentences.original: êkosi sipwêhtêw, êh-âmaciwêt.
sentences.english: So she went from there, up  the bank.

sentences.original: êkotah kâ-wâpahtahk êh-misâyik wâtih.
sentences.english: There she saw a great cave.

sentences.original: mâskôc êwakoh awa kinêpik wîkih, itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “No doubt the lair of that serpent,” she thought.

sentences.original: êkosi sipwêhtêw, êh-itohtêt otawâsimisah, êh-âcimostawât êh-nipahât.
sentences.text: êkosi sipwêhtêw ê-itohtêt otawâsimisa ê-âcimostawât ê-nipahât
sentences.english: Then she went from there to where her children were, and told them of how she had killed it.

sentences.original: êkosi ôki oskinîkiskwêwak namoya wîh-wâpamêwak, êh-kostâcik.
sentences.text: êkosi ôki oskinîkiskwêwak namôya wî-wâpamêwak ê-kostâcik
sentences.english: Then those young women did not care to see it, for they were afraid of it.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwêyikohk êyôkôw âcimowin.
sentences.english: That is the end of this story.
